data.text: Stealthy Way of Accommodation: Anyone Cycled with Wild Camping in the EU and in the USA?

Anyone cycled for month + with wild camping üèïÔ∏è with tent as preferred way of accomodation? Have you experienced any issues with officials/local rules and restrictions? I know there is restrictions for wild camping in many EU countries, don't know about Asia etc. Share your experience. We cycled in Estonia, where in most places wild camping is allowed, but still many restrictions apply. Basically we had to "break" couple times some rules and wild camp in areas, where wild camping officially not allowed. Do you use such approach - if you can't find allowed area for wild camping, you just put your tent whenever you can, because you have no choice?

I sleep in a hammock so more stealthy haha use a camo tarp and hammock can stash my bike underneith my tarp i do mostly wildcamping im from holland and here it isnt allowed also not in germany belgium and some parts of france so i just find a stealthy spot to hang and get up early next morning
data.author: Menno Pieters

data.text: yes, I'm not yet "ready" for hammok, for some reason I believe , hammok can't be comparable in terms of comfort with tent. Maybe one day I will change my mind
data.author: Andrei Sevela

data.text: look into the haven tent its a hammock style tent with flat laying get a bigger tarp to stash the bike underneith or use the bike as poles to make a awning with the existing tarp buddy of mine does this too since then switched to a bridge hammock for also a flat lay and to save some weight
data.author: Menno Pieters

data.text: Once you've tried a hammok,you'll go straight back to a tent.
data.author: Neil Hornby

data.text: seems to me like you have never had a good nights sleep in a hammock
data.author: Menno Pieters

data.text: You're right,I've never had a good one,they're great for daytime lolling even napping,but I have to be flat to sleep properly.I would have made a crap sailor.
data.author: Neil Hornby

data.text: then u have not tried a good hammock i can lay as flat as i want even on my side and stomach ü§£ just need a proper hammock system that suits your kind of sleep i cant sleep on my back so a normal hammock would not have worked for me either since im a side/stomach sleeper but there are so many system out there that mimic a hammock but have flat sleeping as their primary goal like the haven tent or amok draumr and some bridge hammocks like the ridgerunner
data.author: Menno Pieters

data.text: Yea you are confusing a regular hammock with one specific to camping. You can definitely lay completely flat with a proper hammock. And with a tarp/rainfly set up it's dry and heavenly.
data.author: J-not Jason Kellum

data.text: indeed i was thinking the same like he only tried the canvas style in a stand hammocks which are only meant for relaxing

data.author: Andrei Sevela

data.text: You're right I have only tried 'maggots' A friend of mine has got one of the type you're talking about. He said "it's great,flat,comfortable. But you do need trees". If I had the space I would carry all kinds of options but I can find ground anywhere so a tent it has to be.üç∫ Happy cycling pedal turners.
data.author: Neil Hornby

data.text: yes trees are nice when flying a hammock lol
data.author: J-not Jason Kellum

data.text: I find sleeping in my hammock tent waaaay more comfortable than sleeping on the ground. I easily sleep flat in it. However, there is no room for my gear inside a hammock tent. It has a great built in bug screen. The rain fly comes off.
data.author: Heidi Douglass

data.text: Biggest problem I found was curious dogs in the morning. Apart from that I've never been asked to move on, however I do tend to wildcamp in places where the chance of discovery is unlikely. Sometimes you have to bite the bullet and use what on the surface is a compromise spot. When that happens I sometimes ask locals or dog walkers if it's acceptable to camp and I stress it's only for one night. A green tent helps. I would add that if you are sensible don't over worry about it 99% of the time you'll be fine. These are some of my travels with wildcamping spots.
data.author: Michael Cope

data.text: good thing about being from Scotland, camping is possible pretty much everywhere
data.author: Gary Mcl

data.text: loved Scotland and the outer Hebrides although sometimes finding a dry flat spot was an issue. üòÉ
data.author: Michael Cope

data.text: haha true!
data.author: Gary Mcl

data.text: No risk - no fun...

data.text: totally my approach, that why I'm into 100% wild camping

Klaus Eichhorst
Randy Haluza-delay

data.text: was caught once, last night on a tour ending in Auckland New Zealand. No park close to the city was legal, set up as discreetly as possible but the park guy came around in the evening. After hearing the situation he moved us into the park office‚Ä¶ then came back and invited us to dinner. NZ was a great place to ride.
data.author: Gordon Gilbertson

data.text: I had something like that happen at Yellowstone NP. The found me about 1am, moved me to a more public apace, claiming a bear was prowling around. But the more public space only include a few hardshell cpers, and now I had my food near me too.
data.author: Randy Haluza-delay

data.text: I also had many nights of wild camping in Germany and France and have never experienced any difficulties. I always pick a spot where I can not be seen easily and try to leave as early as possible in the morning. For the most part I really enjoy being that flexibel and setting up your tent right where you are without worrying about finding a campsite.
data.author: Lucas Gottschalk

data.text: that's the point - I don't want to plan my route via official campsites, I need freedom and ability to put my tent somewhere suitable where I will end my my cycling day
data.author: Andrei Sevela

data.text: Where ever you can option is not slim If you bivaque stealth try to be invisible for landlord, police, security Leave early as much is possible
data.author: Dragan Ognjanoviƒá

data.text: I do it a lot in Germany. Put the tent up in the evening and remove it in the morning is the key. Still not everywhere legal. In some states yes (out of a forest) in some other not but who cares? Don‚Äôt make a fire, take your waste with you and it should be o.k. Use a dark green or a camo tent which reduces the risk to get some visitors. Don‚Äôt do it in national parks and protected nature areas, in normal nature parks be carful to be away from places were rangers (very rare) are. Otherwise normal people will not border you and in the very rare case where someone gets angry (I have never heard about it) they may have to call the police and that may take so much time that you can make your way. In the worst case, at last out of official parks, you may get asked to go way. Fines are very rare but in theory possible. But if you are nice to them and friendly not likely that someone is doing it, tell you don‚Äôt know where to go and‚Ä¶. You can also ask farmers to put your tent on they ground ‚Äì normally they are o.k. with this. There are a lot of ways. I like also those simple open huts which are a lot in the nature parks
data.author: Dieter Ploessl

data.text: By the way: My preferred tent for the game
data.author: Dieter Ploessl

data.text: tent name ?

data.text: I like that you can fit your bike in your tent. Is that a section with a bug screen built in on the right side? Can you share the name of your tent please? Thanks
data.author: Heidi Douglass

data.text:
Heidi Douglass and Declan Flynn Lynch Well, the tent is the DD Pyramid tent MC and you can put different inner tents in. I have one with net against bugs and one normal for the cold time. It is relatively cheap compared to my other tents. It is big for one person with luggage and bicycle but too small for 2 with luggage. You can use it also without inner tent. Weight is about 730 gram and 350 gram for the inner tent, so relatively light. https://hammock-outlet.eu/dd-superlight-pyramid-tent-mc.html as inner tent I have those: for cold: https://de.aliexpress.com/item/4000127835327.html?spm=a2g0o.productlist.0.0.30a571f051ccOL&algo_pvid=f472f2b9-afa0-4734-a48e-1656262933fa&algo_exp_id=f472f2b9-afa0-4734-a48e-1656262933fa-0&pdp_ext_f=%7B%22sku_id%22%3A%2210000006292973430%22%7D&pdp_pi=-1%3B66.31%3B-1%3B-1%40salePrice%3BEUR%3Bsearch-mainSearch summer in size M https://de.aliexpress.com/item/4000174291791.html?spm=a2g0o.productlist.0.0.30a571f051ccOL&algo_pvid=f472f2b9-afa0-4734-a48e-1656262933fa&algo_exp_id=f472f2b9-afa0-4734-a48e-1656262933fa-1&pdp_ext_f=%7B%22sku_id%22%3A%2212000024789070795%22%7D&pdp_pi=-1%3B65.19%3B-1%3B-1%40salePrice%3BEUR%3Bsearch-mainSearch

data.author: Lee Laane

data.text: Well what is one month? You have to order such things early and improve the equipment with the time. Aliexpress from China takes always to Germany in between 2 up to 6 weeks and in some rare cases 12 weeks. The DD Camo will be faster within Europe- you will also find something like this in green at Aliexpress even in Silicon-Nylon which is a better material on the long term which I have also but I like the camo. Ali has also very light carbon poles for the tent otherwise a walking stick will do the job. Its really good to hide the tent in the right environment (like in Europe) and light.
data.author: Dieter Ploessl

data.text: i agree, if you have the time, it s worth waiting, i just wanna go before... I might think of taking the random totally not lightweight tent otherwise ok-ish tent with we or try look cheaper smaller a bit more lightweight... This time it s backpacking though, i think... Not sure but depends how we manage... Not too much time to plan(fixed dates with family) but good news, already started tryouts for both... Bike just tried 7+7km trip one side of town no other.. Was harder than thought!! And couldnt look at tte bike for so many days üòÖ and second tte backpaking with a toddler partly in my hiking bag.... Omg!! It s heavy! But mostly as i dont know how to fix the size of the bag to be well proportioned... If i ll do that.. It seems like bikepacking, even with the toddler on back, easier than the bikebacking, for now... For that though i d need a well-working tent.... With all the necessary parts... Imma check that first! Ps. I didnt mention, my idea is however to get fromnortheast to south, and spend some time around there...

data.text: my idea:with or without bike, start fromsweden due to family trip, then from there go down south... Or now more likely, to go there, come back to fix some official stuff im bound to, monthly, then take off to south....through baltics, germany etc...
data.author: Lee Laane

data.text:
Yes all not so easy at the beginning. You can also look at Ali, they have a lot of this pyramid Tents, best would by in Silicon Nylon. There are also bigger ones, like this: https://fr.aliexpress.com/item/1005002693419752.html?spm=a2g0o.productlist.0.0.4ddd79684lJDg2&algo_pvid=7026a67e-0e85-4355-a6d0-26a523d67b41&algo_exp_id=7026a67e-0e85-4355-a6d0-26a523d67b41-59&pdp_ext_f=%7B%22sku_id%22%3A%2212000021742796164%22%7D&pdp_pi=-1%3B127.32%3B-1%3B-1%40salePrice%3BUSD%3Bsearch-mainSearch But if you never start you will never see. Keep on improving everything and next time go for 30, after for 40, 60 and maybe 80 km a day. Always keep on doing and improving. Make every month or 2 a trip for 2 to 4 days and sometime longer. Make notes of what should to be improved for the next time and search for a solution: We are always ready to help. If you are passing by Germany contact me, eventually I'm here and join for a few days‚Ä¶

data.author: Dieter Ploessl

data.text: The more east the less controlled. Asia, apart from a few countries like Japan or South Korea- people don't care at all. Japan and South Korea also wild camping paradise but with more rules in mind (never cross private property).
data.author: Ewa ≈öwiderska

data.text: Japan and SKorea are wildcamp heaven. Legal everywhere on public land, even in cities. I camped within Kyoto 3 nights in different spots. I never hid my tent. One night dusk to dawn legal. Same with South Korea.
data.author: Birgit Le Blond

data.text: that's what I wrote, right? camping paradise. I spent 5,5 month cycling and wildcamping in both countries, countryside and cities. What I meant though is that when you - even by mistake, which happned to me a few times - cross the private land than it is really taken bad.
data.author: Ewa ≈öwiderska

data.text: Oooops. It says 'apart from Japan and SKorea'.
data.author: Birgit Le Blond

data.text: I have a lot of experiences for wild camping in Asia. Mainly Japan but have Philippines, Thailand, Indonesia. If corona restrictions will over I'll go more countries. If you're interested in the scenes of wild camping of mine please check my photo albums üòä
data.author: Takashi Oyama

data.text: I've wild camped thousand times in last 14 years I've been doing bicycle touring. Few times i was found and forced to leave, few times people called police (mostly England), in rare occasion i was guarded by soldier but mostly fine. Green tent is the way and at least some bush/trees help a lot. Best pitch up in the dark and leave in the dark but mornings are always less stressful. Camped in all continents and still think Europe is the best. Most difficult country to wild camp was England (Scotland on the other hand is fantastic) and best Sweden/Finland. But i have a strong feeling that on one beautiful day I'll be shot for trespassing :-)
data.author: Beggard Beggar

data.text: Like you I've wild camped everywhere,I'm surprised you find it hard in England for me It's the easiest there are so many places to hide away even close to the road. The Two rules I use are not to camp where pedestrians can reach,and not to camp where vehicles can reach. I have always got away with it. For me the hardest place is the Netherlands,it seems like every inch is owned and not many hide away places,I'm going to try at least One night wild there this year when I make my trip. I love the feeling of starting my days riding already with a sense of small success for the nights sleep. Good luck.
data.author: Neil Hornby

data.text: I got my tent, while I was unexpirienced hiker/cyclist. It has light grey colour. I should get dark green tent instead
data.author: Andrei Sevela

data.text: The day you will be shot is likely, IMHO, to be in the land of the free. (My neighbour to the south.)

data.text: 7 years living in a tent - not one problem

data.text: If you are checked while in a forbiden area, just explain that you were very tired and obliged to stop to rest. Most people will understand and accept it, if you add that you will be leaving soon in the morning, leaving no garbage.
data.author: Jean-Marc Combret

data.text: yes, exactly what I will do if such situation will occur. I believe most people will be kind and will understand situation
data.author: Andrei Sevela

data.text: In some countries they are sick and tired of the brown cakes ,some ppl leave when wild camping. Some LBS have in stock small plastic shovel to dig a hole and drop the "stuff" in there. best is to pick the right spot (away from creeks) in the evening to make the hole , then in the morning we don`t have to rush to get that business done. The other day someone said "and i stick a little flag in it for the local farmer" ...the shovel below is made of titanium, 35 grs. --------obviously ideal is to stop at public WC like in gas stations before heading wild camping.
data.author: Jo En Pausa

data.text: I avoid that as you never know who might see you and, with bad intentions, sneak up on you in the middle of the night, assault you, etc.

data.text: that's the key of wild camping. Be safe. Be invisible.
data.author: Andrew G. Szabo

data.text: Wild camping? Wait, is there another way?
data.author: Andrew G. Szabo

data.text: Point is not to get cought! I never got cought so no clue what happens if you do. I truly believe one of our basic human rights is to live on this planet as we choose...as long as we don't harm others (there is no "others") or the planet. Wildcamping is part of that right imho. Usually 1 or 2 hours before dark i look for a spot. When found, before unpacking, first make a coffee, chill. Just feel the place and see if someone is coming. Then unpack. Don't put my tarp yet. Some cooking and eating. If someone comes, ask their opinion about you camping there. My experience is people or don't mind/are positive or point you to a better spot. In my point of view, being stealthy/sneaky makes you suspicious...I just act as if I belong (which we do!), works for me... Intuition is important!, follow yours... Be nice!, always... Never panic, and if you do...just stop, coffee, think. Never take important decisions when on panic! Leave no trace The world is yours!, Own it
data.author: Barry Kwaaitaal

data.text: all ok except trash, toilet paper, excrement etc.etc.

data.text: Wild pig encounters in parts of France and Italy are unavoidable so I hang my garbage and opened food packages in the trees. Poisonous snakes in Turkey are a big concern but you learn where not to find them. Agricultural areas with working or protective dogs can be difficult as they'll bark all night if they know you're on their land. Agricultural areas, in general, can be difficult because all the land is used and you may encounter lots of fencing. I will leave major roads when looking for a camping spot. I drag my bike to strange heights if needs be.
data.author: Marshall Bradbury

data.text: This is stealth camping at its finest, but I don't generally need to be or like to be quite so hidden. And Turkey is a 5 star country for wild camping.
data.author: Marshall Bradbury

data.text: More than half of europe it is illegal and campgrounds cost as much as hotel rooms. So I stopped caring and wild camped. The chances of being seen are small, the chances of being reported smaller, the chances of meeting up with rangers/police yet smaller and the chances of being actually fined are next to nothing.
data.author: Mindaugas Jokubonis

data.text: I have to slightly disagree. Camps for 12-17 euros with warm shower and wifi. Hotels 60e minimum.
data.author: Stephen Dexter Jr.

data.text: I've payed up to 25 euro for a tent spot. And there are always cheaper options in hostels, booking or airbnb where you get the same deal or even more than a hotel room.
data.author: Mindaugas Jokubonis

data.text: my tent is cheaper than that ü§î
data.author: Lukas Rak≈°telis

data.text: , the pricing is insane! Go for it!
data.author: Rene Ordman

data.text: Funny how some think that 12-17 EUR is "cheap."
data.author: Ignacio Duran

data.text: Stealth camping means nobody knows you are there or were there. If you master that it doesn't matter.
data.author: Rick Feightner

data.text: to that end ‚Ä¶ I eschew a tent
data.author: Andrew Rowe

data.text: Have to say that I'm lucky that in Finland you can put your tent almost any place. For example parks in city centers excluded and the private yards (but you can temporarly sleep any privately owned land as long it is no ones backyard)... But the hard part is that Finnish nature is swamps, rocks, lots of trees, bit more trees and lot more trees. You better look beforehand a good map to save time. Dry coniferous forest is the best. Good part is that there is no dark in summer so you can keep looking the map all night. Often cyclists go late in the evening to small beach and put there a tent, especially if you cycle out of the big cities. Not officially allowed but really there is no one to care. You will not get a fine for doing that. We also have free primitive huts and some of those can be close to cycle routes.
data.author: Jenni Kylm√§koski

data.text: Yes there are lots of 'huts' in the Finnish forest, often even with fireplace, toilet too! Mosquito net is recommended! But yes, aim for a lake beach and you will do well! Love cycling in Finland! (Anyone üöµ‚Äç‚ôÄÔ∏è in Pirkanmaa, Finland, & you may visit my place for hospitalityüòä
data.author: Allison Hopkins

data.text: you welcome to visit your neighbors - Estonia üôÇ. We are very similar to Finland in all terms

data.text: In national parks the fine is up to a thousand euros. But I did see them camping. I don't hope so, too much of a fine. Otherwise yes, go to the forest, set up a tent and in the morning further. ü§£üòú
data.author: Bojan Lorger

data.text: My understanding is that in Ontario, Canada, "wild" camping is officially illegal, except on "Crown Land", which is difficult to find near most roads. I more prefer the term "Stealth" camping, which has one rule only: Don't get caught. (Set up at dusk, set down at dawn.)
data.author: Peter Lehman

data.text: If it‚Äôs illegal to camp in an area it‚Äôs only for campsites to make money
data.author: Dave Prestidge

data.text: in Poland generally forbidden, many people do anyway. Legally, recently, in state forests in certain areas allowed.

data.text: I try to find a spot while still light out - then go run errands or go to the pub. Set camp camp after dark and then get up at first light
data.author: Kent Robinson

data.text: I camped where I can
data.author: Gustavo Rodriguez Lavecchia

data.text: I've lived for years sleeping like this, but just the past two years on a bike. I do my best to remain hidden. The only issues I've had were when I was in populates areas and was desperate for sleep.
data.author: Benjamin Moravec

data.text: just wait til after dusk. make sure off trail approx. 100 ft. no fires. leave early morning. never had an issue.
data.author: Zachary Markis

data.text: I've camped wild dozens of times in and around what I believed was private Property. Nobody said a word. However, as a tip. Have a spare inner tube with you and tell anyone that catches you that you had a flat (show them the tube and puncture repair kit and pump) that you had just used the night before and explain that you had no choice but to settle here for the night...The main thing to put across is that you are intending to leave as soon as possible for you have a set plan...Basically, they don't want people staying for a period of days...
data.author: David Eldred

data.text: hmm, interesting idea. But I think, saying people, that you don't have time to look for another place to pitch your tent, because it's soon will be dark, might be a better idea.
data.author: Andrei Sevela

data.text: as they come back and say, then why didn't you cycle to the nearest bnb? Nevermind. I've just got tens of thousands of miles experience. You obviously know it all...Good bye.
data.author: David Eldred

data.text: I don't know all, that why I opened this thread, to gain knowledge
data.author: Andrei Sevela

data.text: listen up. You go to a foreign country where you don't speak the native tongue. You happen upon a farmer who is about as likely to know English, your language or any other. Then he comes enquiring as to why you are on his land and you say...Oh, it's getting dark and I thought I could stay and he says Bal bla Bla, basically he hasn't got a clue about what you are saying. However. if you do it using MY advice you look at him, hold up your inner tube and pump and then (Unless he's an idiot) realises that you've burst your tyre and had to repair it so you were compelled to stay. Now, do you get it?
data.author: David Eldred

data.text: In spain it is forbidden to plant a tent until its dark, and by sunrise it has to be packed. On the other hand, i use a winter hammock. As long as i use trees no one has told me anything
data.author: Jordi Romero

data.text: Juste hide as well as you can...
data.author: Bernard Magnouloux Montpoulet
Klaus Eichhorst

data.text: Forget about the law(s), just avoid people.
data.author: Ignacio Duran

data.text: Yes, 7 mth France, Spain, Switzerland, Germany & Poland just cook dinner earlier (around 4 or 5 pm in summer) and then continue until you find a spot to pinch the tent. A lot of times we sleeped in (small football) stadiums or on fishing clubs property. Just leave no trace!
data.author: Christian Tydecks

data.text: we should specify what is meant by camping or bivouac. On the national territory free camping is forbidden, but if you show that you are bivacating it is already different, if you start setting up a tent at 4 in the afternoon, to light a free fire on the ground with a lot of grill on top you can't say you are biv igniting, but if at sunset you open a small tent you can always say that you are in transit to that before dark you have organized yourself to spend the night (kind of like spending the night lying on a bench in a park) this happened to me at Elba, the forest saw me, it wanted to v edere i documents and they told me that in the morning by 8 o‚Äôclock I had to dismantle everything, so I did and at 7 I had made sure there was no trace of my bivacus.
data.author: Giovanni Baracchetti

data.text: I‚Äôm going to Cuba May 30 for 30 days w/Brompton & tent
data.author: Pali Aha

data.text: No problem
data.author: Kekar T√°riq

data.text: Be discreet, take your rubbish with you, if you run into trouble be polite and move on. I went from slovenia to greece freecamping most of the way and never had any issues, slept on beaches, in forests, shrubs beside a road if needed. Usually set up around sunset and packed down at sunrise üôÇ have fun!!
data.author: Anna Nagy

data.text: Well, going around with a yellow tent... IQ350
data.author: Alessandro Caliendo

data.text: Well...a bright yellow tent doesn't help üôÇ No, for real, i've been doing that for years and never got cought. Mainly Belgium, France, Germany and Switzerland. Paying upwards of 20Eu for a camping spot is just ridiculous. Find a place just before darkness sets in and make sure you're gone just before sunrise. And...leave no trace of course. Never had any problems, although i have to say that Sweden and Finland were amazing, always more peace of mind when you know you're not breaking the rules.
data.author: Pilecki Dave
